reviewText: This is a very nice complete cycle of Schumann symphonies on DVD, especially considering I don't see any other option even available (at least on Amazon). This DG release is nicely filmed, the audio is well-recorded, and the live performances of the Wiener Philharmoniker in Vienna are really good. I can't say for sure without some closer analysis, but it is likely the same set of late '80's recordings previously released on CD only,Schumann: The 4 Symphonies, which is very highly regarded. If you are a collector like me, and have various "classic" CD versions of your favorite repertoire, but want something comparable on DVD, this won't disappoint.
summary: Great music, orchestra, conductor, good recording, what more can you ask for?
Title: N/A

reviewText: Leonard Bernstein's Schumann symphonies were recorded live in a series of concerts in 1984/85 and originally released on CD and laser disc. DG has cleaned up the video nicely for DVD, and the audio is among the best I have heard on the conductor's later video productions. The (at the time all-male) Wiener Philharmoniker, always a capricious band, are in top form and visibly and joyfully give their very best: ensemble is near-perfect and solo work often outstanding. These are impassioned interpretations which go to the very core of each symphony. Bernstein stresses the "romantic" and the "dramatic" essence of the scores rather than their structural cohesion, but he never loses sight of recurring motifs and even of the intertextuality between symphonies. In his mid-sixties here, he displays enormous elan in his gestures (at times he even appears to become airborne), but with all his flamboyant style it is also obvious that he believes in every note Schumann wrote--and he did write some awkward notes. Humphrey Burton knows the scores very well and spotlights orchestral soloists and groups. These are performances to treasure and to behold: a tribute to Schumann as well as an important facet in Bernstein's invaluable legacy as a cultural giant. Get them while you can!
summary: A tribute to Schumann and Bernstein
Title: N/A

reviewText: Leonard Bernstein, in one of his Young People's Concerts, complained that some conductors, in an effort to be as expressive as possible, overdid it.  Of course those concerts were made long before Maestro Bernstein himself overdid it and in some cases, very badly.  That is the case here in most of the slow movements, especially the one in the 2nd Symphony.  Expression in romantic symphonies is very important but it has to be used with discretion.  In the 2nd Symphony, Bernstein stretches the slow movement like he is pulling a rubber band that is too small.  In the Rhenish Symphony, he treats the gentle intermezzo like a passionate Italian aria.  On the other hand, Bernstein's performances of the faster movements, especially the scherzo in the 2nd Symphony, are simply brilliant.Bernstein's set of the Schumann with the NY Philharmonic is far superior, in my opinion.  It is a shame this set is so flawed since Schumann symphonies are rarely played in the concert hall, with the possible exception of the 4th.  The greatest Schumann symphony (No. 2) and the most entertaining and satisfying (No. 3) are practically never played in the USA.If you can tolerate Bernstein's erratic interpretations, this set is well worth it. The playing of the Vienna Philharmonic is extraordinary. The richness of their string playing is incredible. The videography is excellent.  Unfortunately, there are no extras.One more little quibble.  At the time of this recording, at least 20 years ago, the VPO had no female players.  I enjoy watching a mixed orchestra much better than an all male one.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This set is a joy from beginning to end. Bernstein and the Vienna Philharmonic perfectly and consistently capture the essence and spirit of Schumann's symphonies. While these works are not that easy to bring off successfully, on this DVD the performances develop  naturally and with seeming ease. Bernstein's interpretations are uneccentric and everyone seems to be having a good time. Fortunately the video quality, considering its vintage, is quite acceptable and the sound is good. Warmly recommended.

reviewText: Something he  always loved -- classical music -- he can still point to the desired DVD and then watch/listen in the comfort of his own home. And I love the beautiful background music as I perform my daily routine.
summary: What do you give a man with dementia???
